awd_titl_txt: Anion-driven recognition and assemblies of shape-persistent cyanostar macrocycles
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular recognition and self-assembly are powerful approaches to fabricate materials of complex architecture and to assemble functional systems for applications in environmental remediation, drug delivery, and biomedical sensing.  Prof. Flood at Indiana University studies how molecules interact with each other in order to increase our fundamental understanding of the factors governing molecular recognition and self-assembly. This project also provides student training, usage of 3D printed molecules to enhance scientific understanding, and opportunities for technology transfer. 

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Flood conducts research to understand the factors controlling the anion-driven recognition and assemblies of shape-persistent macrocycles.  There are three specific aims in this project. Aim 1 focuses on examining the factors that affect the formation of complexes between hydroxyanions and cyanostar macrocycles in solution.  Aim 2 seeks to establish the correlation between the anion-driven binding and template-directed synthesis and create prototypes of molecular switches. Aim 3 strives to develop the rules governing the directed assembly of cyanostars into dodecahedra enabling their high-fidelity preparation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overall, we have undertaken pioneering research investigating how negatively charged ions, called anions, are recognized and bonded within the central hole of shape-persistent macrocycles, shaped like donuts, and called "cyanostars". Along the way, we have discovered that anions can also bond with each other. This is an unusual idea that, on the surface of it, goes against the expectations of Coulomb's Law. To resolve this quandary, we show that the anions can support hydrogen bonds between each other. The residual Coulombic repulsion is than canceled out when the two anions are bound up inside the cyanostar donuts. To press home the idea, we showed that it was possible to use these cyanostar-mediated anion-anion bonds to make polymers in collaboration with Prof. Azoulay at the University of Southern Mississippi. In one case, we showed that we could make a glue that is as good as superglue. Because the hydrogen bonding is sensitive to heat, we could also show that the glue could be reversibly stuck much like a post-it note but much obviously with much stronger sticking power. These studies are changing the way we think about anions and their interactions in a fundamental way.

Staying with the idea of anions sitting inside the hole of the cyanostar donuts, we also showed that particular phosphate anions can be made into threads. Such threads are similar to the way in which DNA is created. Thus, we can learned how to thread the 'eye of the donut' with the anionic thread. Along the way, we learnt that we had to make the thread exceed a certain length to avoid the thread from biting back on itself and inhibiting going through the eye of the donut. We also took some effort to alter the cyanostar donuts. We were investigating ways to add a site for bonding to cationic ions. In so doing, we made a new macrocycle that displayed fluorescence, much like glow-in-the-dark paint. What was special about this compound was that the energy of light coming out was so far from the energy of light used to excite the molecule to begin with that the color did not show any aberrations common to many other dyes.

We also recognize the need to exploit the fact that the cyanostars donuts recognize large anions. The capture of large anions is relatively unusual thus motivating us to evaluate some of their potential applications outside of our fundamental research activities. We showed how binding the hexafluoro-phosphate anion, which is a workhorse anion in Li+-ion batteries, helped to improve its conductivity in studies conducted with Profs. Johnson and Shao-Horn at MIT. With Prof. Bachas at the University of Miami we showed how linking the cyanostar donuts together with a molecular tether could produce a sensor for specific anions. In particular, a sensor for iodide, which is important for monitoring thyroid-based diseases and environmental management of radioactive iodide releases, such as in the Fukushima disaster in Japan. 

Over the course of our studies, we have had the chance to advance discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. In total, 3 postdocs, 5 graduate and 2 undergraduate students were trained resulting in 11 authorships and 9 presentations. In addition the PI has given 31 invited lectures (US, Australia, Japan, China, Canada), and has been invited to present at the International Symposium on Macrocyclic and Supramolecular Chemistry. Technology transfer involving a joint project with industry using cyanostars has been undertaken as well as efforts by the PI to support of submission of a patent, and to co-found a small business called, Halophore, Inc. As a means to help broaden dissemination to enhance scientific understanding, the PI and his group held public lectures and posted video content. Towards broadening the participation of under-represented groups, a Latina person, 2 women, and one LGBTQ+ member has been mentored. The PI has also supported graduate students to be founders (2018) of the Graduate Women in STEM group at Indiana University (IU), serve on the organizing committee of IU?s 6th Symposium on Materials Research, to mentor a visiting female student from Germany, and participate in IU Career Development Symposia.
